column4: I'm on a 56k modem and the speed is very slow, everything loads 700 - 900 bytes per second. I read on the Ubuntu forums that someone fixed this by installing and using Gnome-PPP, which I tried, but Gnome-PPP won't find my modem whereas the System->Networking program does, but works slowly. How do I get Gnome-PPP to find my modem?
anyone know?
I have an external hardware modem but my modem only goes 700 - 900 bytes per second in ubuntu
did they say *why* switching to Gnome-PPP would fix things?
no they just said it worked. The other option in another post was to "sudo gedit /etc/ppp/peers/ppp0" and add a speed # to the end of it, but that didn't work for me
if I can get Gnome-PPP to actually see my modem, I can test it myself. ;)
what did you set the 'speed' parameter to?

thanks, I know about adding repos, but when I add multiverse to sources.list and apt-get update it doesn't show transcode in synaptic but transcode IS listed here: http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/multiverse/
is transcode available for hoary?
how can I tell?
it's listed in http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/multiverse/t/transcode but not in my synaptic with multiverse added
check packages.ubuntu.com
I don't think transcode is on packages.ubuntu.com but thanks I'll check, I received this info on ubuntuforums I believe a mod mentioned transcode and the url and said it was unsupported
my impression is that archive.ubuntu.com has *all* packages, i.e., for warty, hoary and breezy. The relevant file(s) deciding what belongs to what are the Package.gz files

thanks for the info - packages.ubuntu.com lists gtranscode which is a frontend, but not transcode. So why does packages.ubuntu.com offer gtranscode and not transcode since transcode is required to use transcode???? That's very odd.
check here: http://packages.ubuntu.com/cgi-bin/search_packages.pl?keywords=transcode&searchon=names&subword=1&version=all&release=all
hoary-backports doesn't have it and hoary-extras isn't on ubuntu.com is it?
no
ok thanks, I'd much rather stick to official Ubuntu repos
fair enough. breezy'll be officially available october 13; if you're patient, you can get transcode then
thanks for your help, I appreciate it. :)
I guess there's always the compiling option. ;)
